title: Ticket #2746: Remote, no-DAGMan POST scripts (and maybe PRE)
description:
In the CHTC, we're frequently running jobs under DAGMan for a single purpose: to use a POST script to verify job success, and on failure RETRY the job. This adds a lot of complexity to the process, making it harder to teach users, harder to debug, chews up scheduler universe slots, and is a general nuisance.

Instead of DAGMan and RETRY, you can use an on_exit_remove expression to gain much the same effect. Unfortunately, on_exit_remove is limited to information in the job's classad. Some programs (Matlab programs are a common culprit) will return 0 on success or failure, so the exit code isn't useful. Thus, we use DAGMan to run a POST script that validates the output.

You could get the same effect by wrapping your executable in a script that runs your read executable then does the check. However, this adds the various problems in writing a wrapper. In particular, we're sharing one exit status for two executables. If "1" is returned, did it come from your executable, or from the script? Either one probably indicates a problem, but it's harder to track down the source. Also, you co-mingle your output and error streams. If you're hoping that the stdout from your program will be clean, your wrapper script can't print any debug messages there.

I'm tired of using DAGMan to handle retries and detecting if jobs failed. I'm tired of wrappers complicating interpreting the output of a job. I think Condor can do better.

Relatedly, one might want to run a script on the remote end to validate the machine before starting your real work. Might also be useful for downloading input files from unusual locations on a machine where you can't install file transfer hooks. Also, a remote post script would be a good opportunity to compress files, delete unneeded temporary files, or handle result upload to an unusual place.

Proposed:

Individual jobs gain the concept of a PRE and POST program. In a submit file, it might look like this: 

pre_executable  = validate_machine
pre_arguments   = 1024MB input.txt
pre_output      = pre-output.txt
pre_error       = pre-error.txt

executable     = my_job
arguments      = --obscure-argument=1 52 input.txt --output=output.txt
output         = main-output.txt
error          = main-error.txt

post_executable = validate_output
post_arguments  = output.txt
post_output     = post-output.txt
post_error      = post-error.txt

universe       = vanilla
transfer_input_files = input.txt
log            = log.txt
queue

When a job starts up, if there is a pre_executable, it will be run. If it returns non-zero, then ExitBySignal, ExitCode, and ExitSignal are set appropriately as though pre_executable was the executable. PreExitBySignal, PreExitCode, and PreExitSignal are set to match. The job then stops, matching the behavior of a failed PRE script in DAGMan. If the pre_executable returns 0, then PreExitBySignal=FALSE and PreExitCode=0.

If there is no pre_executable, or it returned 0, then run the actual executable. When it exits, ExitBySignal, ExitCode, and ExitSignal are set as normal. MainExitBySignal, MainExitCode, and MainExitSignal are set to match.

Finally, the post_executable, is assigned, is run. When it exits, ExitBySignal, ExitCode, and ExitSignal are set as normal. This intentionally overwrites the output of the executable. PostExitBySignal, PostExitCode, and PostExitSignal are set to match.

The final values of ExitBySignal, ExitCode, and ExitSignal are what is written into the job log, and thus what a tool like DAGMan will use to decide if the job succeeded or failed. at_exit_remote and other policies can make decisions based on the result of any of the pre, main, or post executables. Simpler policies can simply test all of them by looking at the ExitBySignal, ExitCode, and ExitSignal results.

The flow of exit codes roughly matches that of DAGMan are the moment: if the PRE fails, nothing else runs. Is a POST runs, its result decides if the job succeeded or failed.

As yet unconsidered: We should pass the exit code from the main executable into the post_executable. DAGMan uses a special $RETURN in the arguments to the POST script; we could do something similar, but probably a different pattern since $RETURN will match attributes in the job ad.
